messageBody:
On 2/6/06, David Saff <saff@...> wrote:
>
> Does it make sense to pass parameters to these test
> methods?


Hell yes :-)

I use method parameters in my "real" code all the time, why couldn't I do
the same in my tests?

Everybody already does it in JUnit today, by the way, but it's fairly clunky
("parameterized test case" is the name of the technique I believe, and it
involves passing these parameters in the constructor, storing them in fields
and using the right field in the method... not exactly intuitive).

There is really no good reason why a test method should be different from a
regular method.


Pluggable Selector, using reflection, is such a metaphor. So, whether
> the cost of this metaphor is worth it depends on the benefit each user
> gets, and how many uses that cost is to be amortized across.


Something that I introduced in TestNG recently and which was very well
received was a BeanShell pluggable selector. In short, you can write a
quick snippet in BeanShell (interpreted Java) that will make the decision of
whether to include a test method in the current run or not.

It's a great way to provide the ultimate flexibility in case the regular
mechanisms (test groups, class inclusion/exclusion, etc...) are not flexible
enough, like for example "run these test methods on week days and these
other methods during weekends".

See here <http://www.beust.com/weblog/archives/000325.html> for a quick
illustrations (with screenshots!).
